awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Enabling New Methodologies for the Synthesis of Polycyclic, Complex Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Corinna Schindler at the University of Michigan.  Her research group is developing new synthetic methods for the rapid synthesis of naturally occurring complex molecules of biological importance. The research described seeks to develop sustainable methods using either environmentally benign metal-mediated or metal-free processes for the synthesis of structures with multiple rings. Such structures are difficult to access using currently available synthetic technologies. The focus on organic synthesis is an integral component of Professor Schindler's educational plans, which include training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, both in large introductory science classes and in her research laboratory. She also is involved in outreach programs designed to engage Detroit middle school students to spark and sustain an interest in natural product research. 

The overarching goal of the research project is to address the challenge of selective carbon-carbon bond formation in complex systems. Professor Schindler's studies are establishing new synthetic approaches to enable direct access to two classes of important building blocks. Specifically, her group is developing a formal carbon dianion linchpin strategy to yield polycyclic 1,3-dione building blocks common to many biologically active target structures. The linchpin strategy provides a one-step alternative to multi-step sequences relying on harsh reaction conditions. Additionally, her group is developing a metal-free, catalytic method to access desirable structural motifs bearing quaternary carbons in a diastereoselective fashion. Together, these new strategies enable the synthesis of complex, polycyclic molecules. The objectives described complement and advance currently existing synthetic methods to enable rapid and efficient access to carbocyclic structures of biological importance. Professor Schindler's outreach includes a "Natural Products in Bloom" program developed with the Matthaei Botanical Gardens in Ann Arbor that is designed to stimulate interest and positive public perception of synthetic organic chemistry in the general public.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: This grant addressed the challenge of selective carbon-carbon bond formation in complex systems. Synthetic studies established two new synthetic methodologies to enable direct access to two classes of important building blocks. Specifically, 1) an aluminum-mediated Dieckman cyclization reaction was developed which establishes acid chlorides as formal dianion synthons to yield polycyclic 1,3-dione building blocks common to many biologically active target structures. Importantly, this method provides a one-step synthetic alternative to current multi-step sequences relying on harsh reaction conditions. Additionally, 2) a new approach for catalytic, reductive aldol reactions of highly substituted alkenes was developed proceeding under metal-free conditions. This new method enables rapid access to desirable structural motifs bearing quaternary carbons in a diastereoselective fashion.

As measured by productivity, the impact of this funding can be seen in the publications and presentations that have arisen during the granting period to disseminate the results to the broader community, which include 11 peer-reviewed publications and more than 30 presentations and posters given by undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows at local, regional and national meetings. Additionally, training opportunities for >15 undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows have been facilitated by his research funding, which similarly also enabled two distinct outreach programs.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this grant are multi-fold. The long-term goal of the Schindler laboratory’s research program is to provide the scientific community with new, enabling methodologies for the synthesis of complex, polycyclic molecules of biological importance. In the context of this research program, both graduate and undergraduate students gained profound experience and hands-on training in a scientific research environment. The integrated educational plan of this award built on previous experience of regularly leading two outreach activities, targeting elementary and high school students since the start of my independent career.  The overarching goal of this educational part of this grant focused on sparking and sustaining an interest in STEM research areas across a range of ages, educational levels, and socioeconomic and cultural backgrounds with a particular focus on underrepresented groups. To achieve these goals, work towards two specific aims was conducted that targeted multiple scholastic levels. Specifically, 1) an outreach event was advanced to engage high school students in hands-on research activities at the University of Michigan as part of the Michigan Science Scholars program (MMSS). Additionally, 2) two difference courses were design as part of the FEMMES program (Women+ Excelling More in Math Engineering and Science) to engage current elementary school girls of the greater Detroit area in hands-on science experiments to foster and early interest in STEM.  

Michigan Math and Science Scholars Program (MMSS). We have organized and supervised the Michigan Math Science Scholars course on Green Chemistry, Catalysis and Solar Energy Conversion together with the Stephenson Research Group at the University of Michigan since 2015. These courses last for two weeks (two sessions each summer with ~30 students) and are aimed at introducing a diverse set of high school students to advanced concepts in catalysis with an emphasis on sustainable chemistry. This educational program requires each of the graduate students in the group to design an experiment adhering to the course's goal of Green Chemistry, Catalysis, and Solar Energy; preparing a written step-by-step laboratory procedure for the students; supervising and teaching the students for a day-long session; and finally to encourage students to actively participate in hands-on activities and field-trips to Cayman Chemical, Dow Chemical, and a local botanical garden where the students learned about chemicals in nature. The ultimate goal for this program is to encourage high school students of various backgrounds to become excited about the STEM fields.

Women+ Excelling in More in Math, Engineering and the Sciences (FEMMES). The FEMMES program offers the opportunity for research groups at the university, across multiple scientific disciplines, to design and lead activities that educate local elementary school-level girls about each group's respective research fields.  Every semester, graduate students in our group organize a day of fun, chemistry-focused demonstrations and activities (e.g. making liquid nitrogen ice cream) for the goal of introducing elementary school-level girls to basic chemistry concepts in an exciting, hands-on manner.  Through our participation in the FEMMES program, we hope to actively reach out to young girls in the community to help them foster an interest in chemistry, as well as develop greater knowledge and confidence in learning about STEM fields.


Last Modified: 07/22/2022
Modified by: Corinna S Schindler
